summary: early essential host defense mechanisms involve induction of alpha/beta interferon (IFNAR) and signaling through the IFN-/ receptor (IFNAR) to upregulate IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) ISG expression is associated with numerous biological activities, including antiviral and immunomodulatory pathways. FN-/ and signaling through IFNAR activate ISGs and the “antiviral state”. PRR activation also activates nuclear factor B (NF-B)-regulated genes. thereby inducing proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines to facilitate recruitment of innate and adaptive effector cells. matitis virus (VSV) and theiler's murine encephalomyelitis virus (TMEV) suggested that astrocytes, not neurons, are the main source of IFN- expression. both microglia and astrocytes express various PRRs. astrocytes regulate CNS homeostasis, support neuronal function, and participate in formation and maintenance of the blood-brain barrier. murine coronavirus mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) strain A59 infects microglia, astrocyte, neurons, and oligodendroglia following intracranial (i.c.) administration. MHVs are at best poor inducers of IFN-/ (28–30), but they do induce IFN- in microglia/macrophages (18). defective IFN- signaling was implicated by impaired induction of IFN--dependent MHC class II expression on microglia.
